reviews.title: Middle Western Mayhem & Wit
reviews.text: I am an ardent John Sandford fan. I recently purchased and read the complete Prey series and then the complete Flowers series in order, and I'm only sorry I'll have to wait for the next book in both series. Sandford is a novelist with the rare ability to carry over characters and plot elements with complete believabiity while allowing both to develop in interesting, unexpected but natural ways - the only other "serial" novelist who does this nearly as well is Anthony Trollope, and he avoids murders. I re-read these books with pleasure as great or greater than the first reading because the fast-paced narrative and unexpected plot developments pulls you to read fast the first time; the second or third you can pay attention to atmosphere (he's great on significant landscape detail), character growth, and situation development. Sandford writes like a real novelist, not like someone trying to impress academia with his literary exclusivity.

It's also as funny as Robert Parker at his best Spenser level, funnier than Thomas Perry's wonderful Metzger's Dog, and at times almost as funny (without the silliness) as Carl Hiaasen. The dialog is crisp -- classic Flowers, classic Shrake and Jenkins, classic Sandy and Lucas. Ma Forbes and her half dozen rednecks are so charming that they better be back. And the story twists and turns deviously, finally accelerating the reader into an unexpected slough. I loved it. And to anyone who claims they "can tell Sandford didn't write it" I say, "gopher drool."

reviews.title: Perhaps a better movie than a novel
reviews.text:
I awaited this release eagerly and began reading it nearly as soon as it arrived. An evening with Virgil Flowers seemed just the ticket to escape the stresses of my everyday life.

Unfortunately, this installment doesn't hold up as well as the rest of the Virgil Flowers series. More farce than novel sometimes-- who's got the stone? He's got the stone, no she's got the stone, oh look he's coming in the front door while someone else is going out the back door-- it struck me more like a movie treatment that got stretched to book length rather than a carefully planned novel. Maybe this book wasn't as carefully edited as the rest of the series, or perhaps there was some assistance by an unnamed writer, but it didn't flow well and felt choppy in places.

There's some one-line humor, and action, and a moral/ethical dilemma or two, but I liked Virgil better in previous books when he was dealing with more realistic situations and characters more true to southern Minnesota than to Hollywood (former governors notwithstanding). Frankly, this book could have been set anywhere; there's not much Minnesota in it, and the reason I read regional mysteries is for their sense of place. The "villain", if one can call him that, isn't very well developed, and I simply didn't buy that the character would behave as he did; it didn't sit right. The women characters are even less well developed than usual, unless you're speaking of breast development, which gets old as it is nearly the only subject of repartee about one of the main female characters.

It's an okay escapist read as long as you don't set your expectations too high. I wish I'd waited to purchase it, because in the end, it didn't deliver "full price" entertainment. Leave the terrorist plots to Brad Thor and Vince Flynn, and please give us back our Southern Minnesota preacher's boy working on community tragedies.

reviews.title: Virgil Flowers Is on the Trail of an Ancient Religious Artifact
reviews.text:
Elijah Jones is a minister and college professor working on an archeological dig in Israel. He's also dying of cancer and about to leave behind him a wife with Alzheimer's who may wind up living for years with minimal care. Then one day, Jones's team uncovers an ancient stele--a stone with inscriptions carved into it. A preliminary examination suggests that the information on the stele, if accurate, could require a significant reinterpretation of the Bible and could also radically undermine some long-held religious beliefs.

While the rest of the team sleeps, Jones smuggles the stone out of the camp and makes his way back to Mankato, Minnesota. The theft causes an uproar and the Israeli government sends an attractive female antiquities expert to help American authorities recover the stone.

The American authorities in question would be that F****ing Virgil Flowers of the Minnesota BCI. Virgil is hip deep in an investigation involving fraudulent antique lumber and his prime suspect is a very sexy woman named "Ma" Nobles. When Virgil's boss, Lucas Davenport, pulls him off the case and tells him to pick up the Israeli expert and recover the artifact, he's not at all pleased, but figures it should be a fairly easy and simple assignment.

Wrong again, Virgil.

The case immediately takes a lot of unexpected twists and turns, and tracking down either the Reverend Jones or the stele is hardly a piece of cake. Things are complicated because, as word of the discovery spreads, an awful lot of other people both foreign and domestic are anxious to get their hands on the stele. Virgil just wants to recover the damned thing and return it to its rightful owners before anyone gets killed so that he can get back to Ma Nobles and the Case of the Fraudulent Lumber. But that may be easier said than done.

As always, it's great fun to spend time in the company of Virgil Flowers, and this is a pretty entertaining book. To my mind, though, it's not up to the standards set by the earlier Virgil books. The plot is way way out in Dan Brown land and is so implausible that a reader, or at least this one, simply can't suspend disbelief enough to really get into the book. I never for a moment bought into the plot, but I did laugh a lot as Virgil investigated the case as only he can. I'll look forward to the next book in the series, hoping that it returns to form.

This is a different Virgil Flowers (and John Sandford) book. Nobody gets killed (although several people die natural deaths). This is a sort of "Maltese Falcon" mystery about a Hebrew artifact stolen by a dying Lutheran minister which is sought by an assortment of dubious but somewhat loveable ner-do-wells, including a fake Israeli archeologist, several unreliable would-be terrorists, two Turkish fraudsters, a family of Minnesota fraudsters, an several other greedy misfits. The joy in the book is in the interaction of the characters and is more of a "what's happening?" than a "whodunit." The archeological hot potato allegedly casts doubt upon the Hebrew origins of King Solomon and thereby the legitimacy of Jewish claims to the Holy Land, although it is not very clear how.
Flowers is his usual libidinous, clever self, but does not figure out what is going on until near the end, if he figures it out at all. The underlying mystery of the artifact is left hanging, with a clever, twisty and unreliable ending. All this adds to the fun. This is by far the "lightest" of the Flowers mysteries, but probably the most satisfying. It proves that you do not need a bloodbath to make a good detective story.

Perhaps, after reading the Editorial Reviews, some of them thought they might be getting some juicy tidbits related to Dan Brown's anti-Christian Da Vinci Code delusions which were fobbed off to the unsuspecting as nonfiction. Thank God there isn't any of that. This Fiction book only presents a story about an apparently ancient stone with allusions to the lineage of Solomon - enough foundation for provoking interesting conflicts without insulting any reader. And in the end, the stone even proves to be -- well, not to spoil it for anyone, let's just say that its provenance comes into question. There's only one thing that might be offensive. At the very end of the book, Virgil remarks: "Even if the stone had been real, it would have been some pharaoh throwing bullshit at the locals. The BC version of Fox News."

The action is thrilling; the character descriptions are highly enjoyable; and the composition is flawless. This book is LOT of fun!

reviews.title: Big disappointment!
reviews.text:
I’ve been a Sandford fan from day one. His Prey series has been my favorite; I eagerly awaited each new release. Unfortunately, some of his later works have not been favorites, and with Storm Front, Sandford’s latest, the author has hit an all time low. If I hadn’t been a long-time fan, I’d never have finished the book.
Since The DaVinci Code became a blockbusting success, everyone’s writing books about an ancient relic that if made public, would change the world of religion, as we know it. For me, most of them are nothing but 400 page chase scenes. Not my personal taste, but they have become extremely popular.
Who could imagine Sandford fitting this type of storyline into a Virgil Flowers novel! Storm Front stars Virgil Flowers, a character who, like Lucas Davenport before Sandford married him off, is a super-sleuth, and super-successful womanizer. The story opens when Flowers is assigned a case involving an ancient inscribed stone, whose message, if shared with the world, would create chaos in the middle east. The man who stole the stone from a dig in Israel is from Minnesota and is known to have returned to the US with it. Flowers is assigned the case, begins looking for the man, finds the thief missing (of course!) and within a matter of days, he encounters at least four factions (all armed and dangerous) that are also in pursuit of the stone, which is estimated to be worth millions of dollars.
Now, despite the theme of the book, the story does captivate the reader. Flowers is an interesting character, and I did enjoy his investigation and interplay with the people seeking the stone. About halfway through, however, something happened, that if I weren’t a devoted Sandford fan, I would have quit reading the book.
When Flowers finally gets the stone in his possession, did he find a vault to put it in? A bank? A police station? A Brinks truck? People have been shot at, nearly killed, assassins are part of the chase, (not to mention, once more, the thing is worth millions), and Flowers takes it home with him and stores it in his dishwasher. The reader is expected to believe this character, solver of all crimes, would be that stupid. It’s no surprise to the reader that the stone is stolen during the night.
After that I had a hard time forcing myself to finish reading the book, but I finally made it through, extremely disappointed with the story.

reviews.title: Twists and turns until the end
reviews.text:
Elijah Jones, a minister from a small town in Minnesota, had spent many years traveling to the Middle East to participate in archeological digs, including several in Israel. When STORM FRONT began, he was in Israel and had just found a stele. The stele, about 2000 years old, had writing in both hieroglyphics and an ancient Hebrew. Both told the story of a battle. In one, King Solomon was the hero. In the other, an Egyptian pharaoh, Siamun, was. Sandford stated: "David was not a rich and powerful king. He ran a small kingdom." where most of the people were "rural and poor." "Solomon suddenly has enormous riches, a huge treasury...and the Queen of Sheba comes to sleep with him." "The insignificant kingdom had always been under the thumb of the Egyptians." If the stele is true, the Pharoh Siamun was Solomon. It would completely change the history of Israel, raising questions about who its early settlers were and whether today's Jews had a right to live their based on their historical ties. Sneaking out at night, he stole a car, took a cab, hired a boat, and made his way to Cyprus and back home to Minnesota, leaving a very obvious trail including some blood stains. He also took the stele with him.
Elijah Jones was dying of cancer and had only weeks to live. For a reason that is explained about halfway in the book, he decided he needed a lot of money and thought selling the stele would be an easy way to get it.
He was wrong. The Israeli government wants the stele returned, preferably before the information about it is publicized. Hezbollah wants it to support their claims against Israel. A Texan wants as part of his quest to find legendary antiquities and publicize himself. So Jones, who goes into hiding (when he is not hospitalized and snuck out of the hospital) decides to auction it off for $3,000,000.
Virgil Flowers, a lawman from a small town in Minnesota, had as his biggest concern stopping one of the residents from selling fake old wood when he was charged with finding the stele. The task became very complicated as Jones and the stele keep disappearing, the potential buyers attempt to get it by any means possible, and a character's identity is stolen. He finally doesn't believe what anyone says but does his best to get to the truth and capture the stele.
One conversation I found interesting was between Flowers and an Israeli:"Do you believe the Bible?" "Some parts of the histories, yes. Most of it is foundation myths, tall tales, and literature. Do you believe in Moby Dick?""Moby Dick" is a novel, not a history." Do you believe in the details about whaling ships and whaling boats and all that?" "That's the Bible ,... I believe some of it."
Chapter 23 is probably the shortest chapter I've ever read in a book: "Sometimes, a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do." It coverer the topic entirely.
The writing in STORM FRONT was breezy and laid back with wit and humor thrown in. I haven't read any of John Sandford's novels but I know this, the seventh of the series (he has two other series), will not be the last.

Sandford's two major strengths start with his ability to create unusual characters and to develop them to great depths so that you feel that you are getting to know them as you would a real person. He's like an Elmore Leonard of the North! Already looking forward to the next in the series!

reviews.title: An Off Day
reviews.text:
Virgil and his writer are clearly having an off day. I hate to say that considering Virgil Flowers is my favorite series that Sandford writes and now he doesn't write the series completely anymore. I'd rather the two books a year than four lackluster disappointing reads.

Virgil spends a lot of his time threatening people with prison time, which is not new for Virgil, but in the past you believed him, knew he'd follow through, that it wasn't an empty threat.

I loved that in the past that Virgil could take a simple case and turn it into something far bigger than it started. After all, Virgil shot all those Vietnamese. Right? This story left me feeling as though he bumbled his way to solving it. I expect some missteps where Virgil is concerned, but I never lost confidence in him as investigator. Until now.

Let's face it: Virgil wasn't dealing with criminal masterminds. I get there are a limited number of them out there and they do tend to be boring. I just like Virgil to be a few steps ahead of the village idiot.

Another thing I have always appreciated with Sandford's writing is his ability to create a backdrop of interesting supporting characters, and I missed that with this book. There isn't a lot of new places to take story, so characters are so very important to adding depth. Ma Nobles came closest to being interesting.

If Sandford intends to continue lending his name and characters to ghost writers, then those writers need to love and know the characters before they ruin them.

reviews.title: The plot goes on and on and on and on, with a few BIG objections
reviews.text:
This is a long winded story which lost my interest after the half way mark. As another reviewer wrote, "where is the stone, who has the stone, where is Jones, does he have the stone...". Importantly, there is no sense of menace to drive the plot along. One doesn't feel strongly against Jones, nor strongly for him. As in other Flowers books, he winds up having sex with a witness to the crimes he is investigating, which is always bizarre. That seems to be a requirement for each book along with the appearance of at least one "dishwater blonde". I found quite a bit of humor in the dialogue, but overall the book drags along - too many scenes that go nowhere as characters fumble around, show up, disappear and show up again.

One serious complaint I have echoes that of another reviewer. I find the Israeli women trying to find bargains at Sam's Club and Best Buy bordering on stereotypical anti-Semitic cliches that are best edited out. They are the (offensive) equivalent of having an African character slurping up watermelon. In previous books by the author I was surprise to see some strongly anti-gay statements. I could do without this kind of thing in the thrillers that I choose to read. Unnecessary at best, offensive at worst. It doesn't matter to me when he wrote it. Racist stereotypes aren't amusing.

And then the constant harping on the size of a character's breasts, at least three times in the book.

"She had no trouble floating, Virgil thought, probably because she had built-in water wings."

Puerile, juvenile objectification. I really don't know how he can write this stuff without some sense of shame or embarrassment.

I would say I am done with this author.

reviews.text:
From the outset, this book didn't grab me, and it got worse. I've enjoyed a lot of Sandford's books in the Flowers series, as well as Davenport. Not this one. I don't give up on books often, but I quit Storm Front.

First, I found it hard to follow who all the characters were. A lot of stereotyping of foreign characters, and after a few dozen times you get tired of bungled American idioms by them. I kept hoping the end was coming but then the book jumped the shark.

Without giving much away, I'll just say that Flowers carelessly mishandled evidence. He even had his two buddies Shrake and Jenkins available to help secure it, but he sends them home. He tells Davenport he's got the evidence, and instead of telling him to bring it in right away, Davenport just congratulates him and hangs up. And he makes sure at least one more person involved know that he's got it. Would any cops really be so stupid? Probably not, so it was insulting to me as a reader to be subject to it, to keep the book going.

I read a couple more chapters, then just skimmed a few pages and then skipped around at barely glanced at pages I landed on until the end. I never did figure out what finally happened, and found that I didn't care at all.

I've had to skip around the series a bit due to library availability and I've already read the next three in the Flowers series and they were good, so I'm hoping this is a one time stumble.

reviews.text: So far, the Virgil Flowers novels have been a fun return to Sandford in his prime- right up until "Stormfront," that is. I don't know what possessed John to write this, but it was obviously meant to be a much lighter, more humorous novel in the series (which is itself lighter and more humorous than the Kidd or Prey series). Maybe it exists solely for the dramatic change of pace it brings; whatever the reason, I didn't hate this book, but I sure was disappointed by it. The premise is utterly ridiculous, the characters are stereotypes and the plot feels like he was making it up as he went along. To be fair, it still has its lovable protagonist, "that effing Flowers," and there are the series' signature laugh-out-loud moments and catchy dialogue. But those are pretty much the saving graces. If not for the introduction of "Ma," the book would be a complete waste of time. Hopefully, Virgil has met a female nemesis who will stick around for a few books.

reviews.title: Like a Parody of a Virgil Flowers Novel
reviews.text:
Virgil (nicknamed "that F***in' Flowers" by his police buddies) has always had a bit more comedy to him than Sandford's other police novel hero, Lucas Davenport. But in "Storm Front," a lot of the comedic attempts are of the kind more likely to elicit groans than genuine laughs. To me, this book seems more like a parody of a John Sandford novel, than an actual John Sandford novel. The book is full of caricatures rather than characters, and there aren't any homicides to solve. (I prefer a novel with a lower violence level than, e.g., the Jack Reacher books - one or two murders per novel are plenty for me. But the plot of this one just felt like the stakes were too low to be very interesting. I'm not a fan of "religious mystery" plots.)

I heard Sandford's interview on NPR several months ago, in which he said that other writers would be involved in drafting "Sandford" books from now on, to enable more per year to be published. This is the first new book by "Sandford" I have read since hearing that interview, and I have to say, I think the quality of the writing has suffered. I hope Sandford and his collaborator(s) get better at the new system of turning out "Sandford" novels, so I can enjoy future ones as well as I did the earlier ones. Lucas Davenport and Virgil Flowers books have always been 4- to 5-star quality, before "Storm Front."

reviews.text: John Sanford builds truly memorable characters that make you want to keep following through their various adventures.  Lucas Davenport is the best known, but his Virgil Flowers character is, in many ways, more likable.  Virgil gets into some truly extraordinary situations, usually as a result of an assignment from his boss, the aforementioned Lucas Davenport.  He is a very unassuming and likable character who is most happy when he is fishing and writing stories for outdoor magazines.  Coupling that with good looks and a great attitude toward women, makes him a babe magnet, even when he doesn't want it.  Virgil Flowers stories are frequently touched with a fair amount of tongue-in-cheek humor that makes them even more readable.  This is a really good example of Virgil's exploits and you won't regret reading it.

reviews.title: But most of the time, the sun is out
reviews.text:
Storm Front is by far the funniest of the wry Virgil Flowers books, and I was laughing out loud through much of the book. It's more of a Keystone Cops romp around the environs of Virgil's hometown of Mankato. Turns out a local Lutheran cleric and professor of archeology has stolen a rare and history-altering "stele" from a dig in Israel. And lots of parties want to steal/buy/borrow/publicize it. We've got the Hezbollah, the Israeli Mossad and the Israeli Antiquities department, the Texan fundamentalists and the host of an Ancient Mysteries TV series. Each of these bidders is painted in the deft spare brush strokes of true Sanford mastery.

Virgil himself is in rare form. He would rather be skinny-dipping in the swimming hole with Ma Nobles, an alluring redneck mother of 5 boys who is more than she seems. These characters run, ride, truck and swim east, west, north and south along every highway and track and river in southern Minnesota - chasing that stone, which may or may not be fake. And of course, Virgil stays in touch with his boss at the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, Lucas Davenport by phone and radio.

I hate to put any undue pressure on our already prolific John Sanford, but please, write the Virgil Flowers books more quickly, more often! These are soooo good, delicious. In fact, this most recent outing for the Minnesota cowboy cop whose self description is "a taller, younger Robert Redford", is lighter and funnier than earlier books. Bad Blood, in 2010, was darker, disturbing. Storm Front should be called Mostly Sunny.

reviews.title: Really John?
reviews.text:
Add me to the list of John Sandford fans who are severely let down by this one. This, as far as I'm concerned is Sandford's first misfire.

Well, wait. . . .did he even write this one? That's questionable. I'd like to think that he didn't. I'd hate to think that Sandford has joined the James Patterson Club(you know, putting one's name on books he really didn't write?), but perhaps he has. This book certainly didn't read like a Sandford novel. As I was reading it, something felt. . .off, as if maybe an impostor had written it.

Like most fans, I anticipate new releases from my favorite authors, so when Stormfront came out, I promptly fired up my Kindle and bought it. When I found out that the story was going to involve some ancient religious artifact, I was like, "oh oh." These kinds of stories never seem to grab me, but I was thinking that since it is Sandford, and since Flowers is the main character, somehow he would make this compelling, so I began reading.

Got to page 50. Not gripped yet.
Got to page 100. Nope, still not into it.
Halfway through the book("Okay, is thing gonna ever pick up?").

You get the point.

What you have is a story about a dying archaeologist who found an artifact while at a dig site in Israel. He fled the site and returned to the States with the artifact. Turns out this artifact could very well rewrite history for the Israelis in a bad way, so they want it. . .and so do other people in the book for various reasons, people ranging from a rogue Mossad agent, to some hot southern belle who wants to jump Virgil's bones. Flowers gets pulled into the situation regarding finding and recovering the artifact and giving it back to Israel. The thief is looking to sell to the highest bidder. A lot of meandering and bungled attempts to get it back from this elusive, dying thief occur. If it's any comfort, no one in this book dies(wait, doesn't Virgil usually deal with murders?)

Now,does this sound like something Sandford would even come up with? Anyway, the book reads like a bad dark comedy, and Virgil comes across as an unwilling participant in the whole thing. It's all very eye-rolling, and none of the characters in the book, good or bad are likable. This is not the Sandford I know. This read like some underling attempting to write like Sandford. Like parody, even.

The book was only around 380 pages, but felt like 500+ because is was SO flat, dull, and uninspired. Had this not had Sandford's name on it, I would have not even bothered to finish it.

I really hope the next Prey book is better than this.

Maybe Sanford was having a bad week and I say week as the book reads as if he wrote it beginning to end in 6 days and watched a Vikings Game on the 7th.  The premise and plot line had great promise. Virgil working with a hot looking female Israeli Mossad agent trying to track down an ancient artifact that might question the ethnicity of King Solomon.  Unfortunately that was not to be. Sanford turns an agent of one of the worlds most efficient, deadly and feared intelligence agencies into a bumbling incompetent . They add in some likable and also fumbling and bumbling  Hamas and Hezbollah wannabes and two Turkish agents who apparently for fun castrate their Kurdish prisoners. Then we add some super secret CIA -FBI-DHS or something like that agents who act like they are trying out for the Agent 99 part in the next  Get Smart  Movie.  There is more but it is just a goofy and disjointed mess. I don't know what Sanford was thinking when he wrote this thing and I can only imagine that his publisher didn't read it before sending the check. This is not what we expect from a author as talented as John Sanford.. like I said, maybe he was having a bad week. The Virgil Flowers character is still a favorite and I hope that Sanford will get him back into some real police work in the next novel.

reviews.title: Not What I was Expecting
reviews.text:
I find myself in a very difficult spot. Having to write a less than glowing review for one of my favorite authors.
I love John Sandford, I've read all of his Prey books and all of the Virgil books. This one just fell short for me.

When Elijah Jones steals a rare find from an archeology dig in Israel, he sets in motion a very serious game of hide and seek. Which could mean death for anyone, and everyone foolish enough to find themselves involved.

Virgil Flowers, is an agent with the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension. He is pretty much the only agent responsible for the southern half of the state. His boss Lucas Davenport tasks Virgil to pick up an incoming specialist from the Israel Antiquities Authority, Yael Aronov, who is coming to the states in search of the missing artifact. What is being called the Solomon Stone. A stone that could rewrite the histories of two very large religions. And if this stone is the real thing, it could be worth millions to the right buyer.

When Virgil meets Yael, something just doesn't sit right with him. She seems hard, just not right to him. And as it turns out, Virgil's instincts are never wrong. Now he not only has the missing stone to find. He needs to find out what Yael is hiding from him. Why she feels the need to lie to him about whom she really is.

They need to find this stone, and Elijah Jones before people start dying.

I had a really hard time with this book. Was it a bad book? No. Was it a bad story? No. Was it poorly written? Not in my opinion. But what it wasn't was a typical John Sandford novel. There was no murder to solve, no mystery to solve. Just a big game of Hide And Seek. The winner gets the stone. A lot of boots on the ground investigative work. Which made the book really drag in spots. There was a point about 3/4 of the way through the book where everything is starting to wrap up, that it felt like the story was going to pick up. The chase scene before the end of the book was great. Exactly what I'm used to reading in one of these books. But when that was over, it just kind of petered out to the end. And I really hated Virgil's choice for a "romance" in this book.

All that being said, I do like this author, and will buy his next book. Fingers crossed that it's better than this one.

reviews.title: Another great Sandford novel in the Virgil Flowers series
reviews.text:
I'm not going to point fingers or name names, but there are several authors I used to consider favorites that I no longer read at all because, after six or eight or a dozen novels in the same series, the characters and/or storylines got too tiresome, predictable or just plain boring. That's why I am so incredibly impressed with what John Sandford has accomplished over the past 30+ years.
In 1980, Sandford (aka John Camp) became a daily columnist for The Saint Paul Pioneer Press, was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize, and won the Pulitzer Prize for Feature Writing five years later. His debut novel was released in 1989. To date, he's written two dozen novels featuring detective Lucas Davenport. I'm not sure when Virgil Flowers first appeared, but he became a protagonist with the 2007 release of Dark of the Moon. Seven more Flowers novels followed, and the Lucas Davenport Prey series is still going strong. The books are as fresh and exciting as ever, and that's the case regardless of which series you choose to read. I could continue to sing John Sandford's praises all day but this is supposed to be a book review so let's get to it.
In Storm Front, Virgil Flowers is given the presumably simple task of retrieving an ancient relic and returning it to its rightful owner. The man currently holding the relic smuggled it out of Israel. He's also old, so sick he's peeing blood, and clearly on the verge of death. Virgil has little trouble tracking him down. Getting his hands on the ancient relic proves to be far more difficult. Standing in his way are an assortment of middle eastern cops, would be terrorists and other crazies, some American opportunists and fortune hunters, and a horny woman who makes a living selling bogus antique wood. Everyone is lying to him and no one seems to realize how dangerous of a game they're playing.
Storm Front is proof that John Sandford is still at the top of his game. He is a true master of the mystery/thriller genre. Like so many previous Sandford novels, Storm Front is cleverly crafted, well written, and the story is told with the style and ease of the consummate pro. Count on generous doses of humor and sarcasm as well. Predictably, it's a must read!

reviews.text:
I'm a big fan of both of author John Sandford's two cop heroes - Virgil Flowers and Lucas Davenport. Now that they're appearing in the same books - in this, the seventh Flowers installment - Davenport is the boss of Flowers, a Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension agent, and the two interact fairly often. It is the more colorful Flowers, though, who is my favorite of the two - probably because he's more laid back, somewhat along the lines of Raylan Givens of the hit TV show "Justified."

Here, Flowers has been assigned to track down the one-time preacher and university professor who apparently has stolen a valuable artifact from a dig in Israel, smuggling it home to Minnesota. As the search for the man and the artifact ensues, Flowers goes head to head with bad guys and gals who believe it to be authentic and are desperate to get it for a variety of reasons (mercenary Turks, Mossad, Hezbollah and even a U.S. millionaire or two).

The plot is a bit reminiscent of a Dan Brown novel, but other than that, there's not much of a comparison. I don't recall chuckling even once when reading any of Brown's books (think <The Da Vinci Code and Angels and Demons), but Flowers never fails to amuse with witty comments and insights. One of my favorites this time out happened when Flowers was having dinner at Applebee's, a popular chain restaurant, where he'd ordered ribs (which, IMHO, are delicious). When he looked over at a couple of other diners who were chowing down shrimp platters, which he'd "considered and rejected, feeling that Red Lobster would have given him a better quality seafood entree."

I do agree with other reviewers, however, that this probably isn't the best book to start with for those who want to get acquainted with the Virgil Flowers series (in fact, some insist Sandford had a co-writer who penned much of it). It moves along quickly, but the story borders on the unlikely and Flowers barely escapes acting and sounding like a buffoon in spots. While it's a fun read that held my attention all the way to the end, it's not Sandford's best.

A lot of reviewers found the plot far-fetched, but I didn't have much trouble with the Dan Brown-ness of it all (after all, why couldn't an ancient relic end up in Minnesota?).  But I did sorely miss ANY sense of danger or suspense.  Since 9/10 of the large cast of bad guys were either harmless bumblers (the Turks) or people who don't really mean any harm (the Israelis), this book can't even be classed as a thriller. But if it's not a thriller, what is it supposed to be?  It could be passed off as a parody of a Dan Brown novel, or some kind of rural satire, but in that case, shouldn't it be funnier? reviews.text:
Well, usually something to do with the book. Unfortunately, the title only comes in in the last 20 or so pages of this train wreck, because, you guessed it, there's a thunderstorm. Obviously they were at a loss for what to call this mess, and rightfully so. I've been a fan of Sandford for a long time, pretty much read them all, and really enjoyed the segue to the Virgil Flowers books. This one's different, and it just plain isn't very good. There's no suspense, dialogue by rote, cardboard characters, lots of inconsistencies, holes in the plot, dumb mistakes in geography, the list goes on. It's as though somebody sat down and thought, well, here's an idea -- an artifact from Israel makes it way to Minnesota. Then we can throw in Israelis, Mossad, Hezbollah, and more uninteresting people than I've ever seen in a Sandford novel. (The "love" interest is named "Ma". Really? Come on.) Can't really write interesting dialogue? That's OK, cause we'll just go back and lift most of it from previous Virgil novels and change it up to fit the current plot. Mostly, except for the original stuff which doesn't work at all.
If Sandford is planning to make himself into the next cottage book producing industry like James Patterson has, with his awful novels, he's on the right path. Unfortunately, it's not a path I will be walking down anymore, and that makes me kind of sad. I've really enjoyed the journey, but I'm not buying any more tickets. Haven't you made enough money, John? Don't go out with junk like this.
Rest in peace, Lucas and Virgil. You were good guys, back when.

reviews.text:
Having recently reviewed "Mad River," and finding it "wanting" at best, I decided to take the plunge and read "Storm Front" anyway. Why not: Sandford has been 1 of my favorite authors, and I've really enjoyed both Davenport and Flowers over the years.

I'm not going to tell you the story...that's Sandford's job and besides I don't want to ruin things for any potential readers out there. But putting it simply, this book was absolute drivel. The story line itself was inane, the characters (sadly, including even Virgil himself in this installment) shallow, and the overall plot and conclusion simply didn't make any sense.

Are you getting the sense I didn't like this book...if so, you're very perceptive. Sorry, but I feel one of the masters of this genre has either lost it, or just doesn't give a spit anymore. C'mon, this book is an insult to our intelligence as well as his, assuming Sandford really wrote it. And Dan Brown has nothing to worry about....Sandford is really out of his element writing about ancient artifacts and the like.

If you're new to Sandford/Davenport/Flowers save your money and time. Read the early Prey books, especially those with Carla Rinker, and by all means read the first 3 or 4 Flowers novels, but stay away from this very unsatisfying effort.

One last point....and I really do NOT want to pre-judge. Along with this book, I also ordered Sandford's "Field of Prey," a new (to me) Davenport installment. I was looking forward to reading it, and likely still will. But given the last couple of Flowers novels as well as the 2 Davenport books prior to "Field" I have to say my expectations are low. Given the great work Sandford has put out over the years I find that kind of sad.

reviews.title: Virgil Flowers Rides Again!
reviews.text:
The snide response would be "it's Virgil Flowers. What more do I need to say?" A lot, actually. Although it has the requisite number of high speed car chases, sudden gun battles and Lucas Davenport lurking in the background, this latest adventure has something more - an honest to goodness "look there it is plot." It also has an ending that will force you to scramble back through the entire book going "wait, is that what happened?" Fair warning: don't peek at the last chapter.

The basic plot is an international mystery starting in the Middle East and then taking you on yet another scramble through the crime ridden streets of Minneapolis / Saint Paul. A precious artifact has been stolen and smuggled back to Flowers land. It is, as usual, only a distraction for the author to introduce his string of fascinating characters ranging from professors of biblical archeology to the always present officer Shank. None of them are as fascinating as Clara Rinker but then, who could possibly replace her?

One other surprise point. You finally get to meet a character that has been frequently mentioned but never seen. The character offers some key plot points but is basically "Oh, there he / she finally is. What a nice person."

A pleasant side suggestion. As with most of Sandford's books, read this one with a map program running. If he says this character is going up a specific road or is turning left at this corner and stopping at the Dairy Queen, by golly there is actually a Dairy Queen.

Another excellent romp with the long haired, over sexed, deeply moral, fishing addicted hot shot Virgil Flowers.

REMEMBER - you have been warned. Don't peak at the last chapter.

reviews.title: A Solid Effort
reviews.text:
I don't see what some are complaining about. Yes, it's true that Sandford uses "writing partners" (it's murky exactly what they folks do, his son claims they are more along the lines of glorified research assistants, other interviews imply they might be more) but that's not new. Sandford (ie, Camp) has used them for years on most of his books to one degree or another.

They aren't the deepest books but they're enjoyable reads when it's time to turn off the old brain for a few hours. The Sandford team does a good job differentiating Virgil Flowers from Lucas Davenport so I enjoy reading them in alteration.

The plot of this is a smidge different than some of the other Flowers (let alone the harder Davenport) books. Not a lot of violence and murder but that also fits Virgil's character. And yes, it takes a turn into Da Vinci territory a bit but personally I thought that was kind of fun: the idea of Mossad agents, murdering Turks, Hezbollah terrorists, Hollywood types, and the like all running around Minnesota of all places was sort of amusing and certainly a different context than we usually encounter such characters. In way, almost perversely so, to have all those folks in one place and yet the story resolves without murder at every step.

I say kudos for writing an interesting mystery -- how will things turn out? is the artifact real or not? -- without resorting to the usual cliches.

reviews.title: Really good read...but missing a certain something
reviews.text:
John Sandford's latest Virgil Flowers book "Storm Front" is a really good read, despite the fact that in some ways an un-Sandford book. The story of a purloined archeological treasure that could be used to rewrite history is quite compelling.

The chase to track down the "Solomon Stone" races back and forth over Minnesota and involves an international cast of characters...you get Mossad, Israeli archaelogists, Hezbollah, Turks, academicians on the make, reality tv stars, with the help of wannabe pilots and local criminals and hustlers-at least of few of which will likely make appearances in future books. The action moves along at a good clip, Lucas Davenport has cameo telephone appearances, and the BCA hard ass squad comes in to provide backup.

There are some of the usual Sandford tactics-like the situation resolving itself, and then spinning back out of control. The author is-as always-very good at juggling a large cast of characters, and has the skill-maybe the literary gift-of writing in such a way that as he pushes you toward one scene/action, you forget about a character...and when that character pops back up it is a surprise.

If you have never read a Sandford/Virgil Flowers book, you will enjoy it. If you have followed the series, you will enjoy it. A good read that I heartily recommend.

So why only four stars? Because it is missing a certain something. This is in a way the most vanilla of the Flowers novels. If you doubt me, read the book and calculate the body count. There is far more slight of hand and skullduggery working here than in most Sandford novels, and that makes the book drag at points. Also, there is a feeling of the generic to the background. There is little of Minnesota in this. Beyond a few local yokel type names for bars and such ("Custard's Last Stand"), there is little of the local color that make both the Davenport and the Flowers novels so interesting. The things that make Virgil tick-going to crime scenes towing his boat, working on an article or thinking item x could make a good article, new references to his background, his ruminations on philosophy-not here.

This story could have taken place in Alaska, Bolivia, Manhattan, Amsterdam, Boston, Nokesville, VA...anyplace. There is nothing really Minnesota to it...and as someone who enjoys the local color Sandford normally brings to the table, that is enough to bump this otherwise highly entertaining book from five stars to four.

reviews.title: Virgil Flowers Returns for Another Tour de Force
reviews.text:
Virgil is, in this case, faced with a very different type of adversary---one who has no motives to do anyone any particular harm, but who needs to commit a crime in order to fund the future for his spouse now that he knows he doesn't have a future of his own. Virgil is chasing a stolen artifact from an archeological dig, and stumbles over lots of other people hoping to claim the artifact, including a sexy and resourceful woman (named "Mom") with grown sons who is a lot smarter than Virgil originally thinks she is. The plot is a merry-go-round with all the interested parties running around Minnesota trying to keep up with the person they know actually possesses the artifact he stole from a dig in Israel. Virgil eventually ties up all the loose ends, but the reader will have to stick with it to the very end to find out what actually happened.

Since Virgil Flowers is my favorite John Sandford character (just ahead of his hacker characters, Kidd and LuEllen, from earlier books) I try not to miss his books. A Lutheran-preacher's-kid police investigator with an edge who is still much loved by his family and usually tries to do the right thing makes for an interesting protagonist.

reviews.title: A Fairy Garden Handbook
reviews.text:
My first experience with fairy gardens came with children's fairy garden author Tracy Kane. I met her one summer when she participated in the Master Gardeners' annual garden fest in Brentwood, New Hampshire. Her work with the children that day amazed me. The kids were mesmerized as Kane helped them build fairy houses under trees and shrubs.

Garden writer and photographer Betty Earl has taken me miles further in this new book about fairy gardens. Here she first gives a cultural history of fairy mythology. The reader even meets fairyologist Jonathan Wright from Ann Arbor, Michigan.

When I read these words that appear early in the book, "The basic idea of fairy gardens is gardening in miniature, creating the illusion that tiny fairy creatures have taken up residence in your garden," I was ready for the book's journey.

What impressed me about this book was how clearly Earl lays out the design of a fairy garden, either indoors or as part of the outdoor landscape, along with the plants and hardscape a gardener might use. Such suggestions appear throughout the book.

The number of photos of plants and tiny garden accessories help the reader experience fairy gardens here, simply by turning the page.

Earl's suggestions for plants, whether the popular Stepables and Jeepers Creepers series or perennials like the lily of the valley, help the reader see that only small, manageable plants fit a fairy garden.

If you want a fairy garden for yourself or you think your children might like to build one, this book is the place to start, easy to read and full of advice on every page.

Also, it’s a beautiful book! The black, red, and white pages, and the black and white fonts, and the different sized fonts, and the raised and impressed text on the cover (and the little fold out flaps) . . . it’s so visually and texturally appealing.

reviews.text: Manage Your Day-to-Day is a useful little collection of essays and ideas for getting control of your work life, remaining creative and avoiding death by email.  I think most people working in today's computerized world with a desk job will find at least a few take-aways in this collection.  There are a number of short chapters, each with a different focus, and different pieces of advice.  There is no overriding plan in this book, no clear map that you must follow, so you can take a few helpful nuggets from the book about managing email, being productive, staying productive, etc.  The book is also a true "pocket book"--you can stick it in your brief case, or keep in on your desk for any time you need a little pep talk.  Some of the pieces tread over the same ground (for instance, a couple authors stress that you should tackle big tasks in the morning when you are fresh, and avoid just sorting through email at that time).  All in all though, this is a useful collection.

reviews.title: Helpful, Brief Thoughts on Improving Productivity
reviews.text:
I picked up this book to add to my goal of improving my productivity and efficiency in all areas of life. As the subtitle suggests, the book's goal is to help you "build your routine, find your focus, and sharpen your creative mind."

Manage Your Day-to-Day includes short chapters by twenty-two different authors. The chapters are divided into four main sections: Building a Rock-Solid Routine, Finding Focus in a Distracted World, Taming Your Tools, and Sharpening Your Creative Mind.

I found the first two sections most helpful, although readers working in more creative professions will benefit from the latter two more than I did. Those two chapters had suggestions on how to inspire yourself to create and how to be creative every day, without becoming overwhelmed by all the technology around us.

This book works well for short bursts of reading, if you want to read no more than five or ten minutes each day. You could read through the entire book in one sitting, but you will benefit more from each chapter if you give it time to sink in.

I enjoyed this book and recommend it for short bursts of reading with a goal of inspiring yourself to work more efficiently.

reviews.title: "Most of us spend too much time on what is urgent and not enough time on what is important."  Stephen Covey
reviews.text:
Jocelyn Glei edited this volume to which she and 20 others contributed their "insights on making things happen," as did Scott Belsky, CEO of Behance, who also wrote the Foreword, "Retooling for a New Era of Work." In fact, this is one of the first volumes in the 99U Box Series published by Amazon. Visit the 99U by Behance website and you will encounter this brief explanation: "For too long, the creative world has focused on idea generation at the expense of idea execution. As the legendary inventor Thomas Edison famously said, 'Genius is 1% inspiration, and 99% perspiration.' To truly make great ideas a reality, we must act, experiment, fail, adapt, and learn on a daily basis. 99U is Behance's effort to provide this "missing curriculum" for making ideas happen. Through our Webby Award-winning website, popular events, and bestselling books, we share pragmatic, action-oriented insights from leading researchers and visionary creatives. At 99U, we don't want to give you more ideas--we want to empower you to make good on the ones you've got."

The brief but insightful essays are divided within four sections: Building a Rock-Solid Routine, Finding [and Sustaining] Focus in a Distracted World, Taming Your Tools, and Sharpening Your Creative Mind, followed by a Coda in which Steven Pressfield responds to this question: "How Pro Can You Go?" Each of the four sections includes a Q&A:

o Seth Godin on Honing Your Creative Practice
o Dan Ariely on Understanding Our Compulsions
o Tiffany Shlain on Reconsidering Constant Connectivity
o Stefan Sagmeister on Tricking Your Brain into Creativity

These are among the dozens of explanations special interest and value to me, also listed to indicate the scope of the book's coverage. The prefix for each is "How to..."

Lay the Groundwork for an Effective Routine, Mark McGuinness (25-29)
Make Room for Solitude, Leo Babauta (59-62)
Banish Multitasking from Our Repertoire, Christian Jarrett (81-85)
Learn to Create Amidst Chaos, Erin Rooney Doland (99-104)
Use Social Media Mindfully, Lori Deschene (133-138
Reclaim Our Self-Respect, James Victore (161-164)
Training Your Mind to Be Ready for Insight, Scott McDowell (183-189)
Let Go of Perfectionism, Elizabeth Grace Saunders (203-209)

With regard to the reference to "a new era of work," Belsky explains: "The biggest problem we face today is 'reactionary workflow.' We have started to live a life pecking away at the many inboxes around us, trying to stay afloat by responding and reacting to the latest thing: e-mails, text messages, tweets, and so on...I urge you to build a better routine by stepping outside of it, find [or recover] your focus by rising above the constant cacophony, and sharpen your creative prowess by analyzing what really matters most when it comes to making your ideas happen."

In other words, "a new era of work" is there for the taking but it will not be given. It must be seized.

reviews.title: A collection of top TED talks in book form
reviews.text:
That’s how I would describe this motivation-dense yet munchable collection of wisdom. The reason I say top TED talk is that it’s accessible and quick—broken up into these 3-6 page mini-chapters—yet reliably filled with incisive, exciting insights from leading thinkers in business, psychology, design, and other fields.

It’s the perfect career self-help book for busy, rushed professionals, honestly: if you have a few minutes during your commute, lunch break, or bathroom break, you have time to ingest one of these energy shots for career and lifehacking. Topics include everything from circadian rhythms to meditation, email management to task prioritization.

So given the title, is this book just for so-called “creative types”? Absolutely not! This information is too precious to keep just to writers, designers, and such; anyone who wants to enhance their productivity, workflow, and life balance can benefit from this invaluable book. In an attempt to fully internalize as much as possible, I took thorough notes, including writing a “key lessons” summary in the margins at the end of every single chapter.

Strongly, highly recommended!

reviews.title: The power of routines and "just showing up"...
reviews.text:
Mundane routines, frequency, solitude, and as Woody Allen put it: "just showing up". Those are the key ingredients for producing great creative work, and making progress on just about any project, both large and small.

The book is short and to the point: each chapter covers a different topic, ranging from value of routines and frequency, to managing your email and social media presence, to benefits of solitude and meditation. Naturally, don't expect in-depth analysis - its sound bites. Having said that, each sound bite serves as a great reminder, and I reckon many of us will find inspiration in at least one of them along the way.

Great read, useful tips. Now back to work, time to work on those routines!

reviews.text:
There are always at least two books on every subject: the first one and the best one. Leadership: Texas Hold `Em style is the best in breed. It is a non-academic, easy to read, practitioner's guide to leadership in life, everywhere from the coffee shop to the front lines.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book, especially the anecdotes and use of the game of poker to further the author's message. You don't have to know about poker to understand the concepts brought forth. I have been a supervisor for a long time and did or was doing many of the concepts that are explained. However, I learned some valuable lessons and was provided further insight on what it really means to be a good leader. I picked up some new ideas that I never thought of and most importantly it teaches you how to work with "bad" bosses: and God knows we all have them! The authors proved once again that we can still be taught lessons and learn from others. I am looking forward to experimenting with these new ideas in the workplace.

"Leadership Texas Hold'em Style" is a great read for the young leader starting out with its wealth of ideas and thought-provoking real-world situations. For the very same reason the book has as much or more significance for seasoned folks in positions of responsibility who simply need to continue to improve their level of expertise and excellence.
As I read the book and was underlining idea after idea, I was struck by how critical the information contained in it is for young people. I immediately thought of my oldest son who is set to graduate from college and how valuable the knowledge included herein is. Clearly he will receive a copy from his dad--his own copy since I will continue to refer to the gems identified as I go back to it again and again. Similarly I can think of any number of friends operating at all levels of business who would benefit by the dozens of ideas and practical issues covered.
"Leadership Texas Hold'em Style" is, as mentioned above, the kind of resource, very much like the Bible, something to return to again and again. Be prepared to read it through once highlighting as you go. Then go back and drill down into those portions most germane to your own situation. Check out the incredibly dynamic supplemental website the authors have created and continue to update. This 'book' truly is a superior investment for everyone who is interested in improving his or her impact/positive contribution to any organization--be it family or business or governmental. Harvey and Foster deliver incredible value. Well done!!!
